Authors:
mahfam barimani, sarah J. Pethybridge, Niloofar Vaghefi,
Frank S. Hay, Paul W.J. Taylor
Title:
Colletotrichum tanaceti sp. nov. a new species causing
anthracnose on pyrethrum
Keywords:
anthracnose, Colletotrichum, biotrophic infection,
heterogenic, Pyrethrum
Abstract:
A new pathogen of pyrethrum (Tanacetum cinerariifolium)
causing anthracnose was described as Colletotrichum tanaceti based on
the morphological characteristics and a four-gene phylogeny consisting
of rDNA-ITS, beta-tubulin (Tub2), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate
dehydrogenase (GAPDH) and actin (ACT) gene sequences. The fungus
produced perithecia in culture requiring an opposite mating idiomorph
isolate in a heterothallic manner. The initial infection strategy on
pyrethrum leaves involved the formation of appressoria followed by
production of multi-lobed infection vesicles in the epidermal cells
which was suggestive of a hemibiotrophic infection strategy. Infection
and colonization then proceeded through secondary hyphae, which resulted
in the initial production of water-soaked lesions followed by black
necrotic lesions. Moreover, phylogenetic analysis indicated that C.
tanaceti was closely related to C. destructivum, C. higginsianum and C.
panacicola that also have similar intracellular hemibiotrophic infection
strategies. Anthracnose is likely to contribute to the complex of foliar
diseases reducing green leaf area in pyrethrum fields in Australia.
